Hello, Heart Hero!

How can you help connect the dots between being active and healthy with your family and friends?

On day five, we encourage you to think about ways to inspire your loved ones to include healthy activities in their daily routine. This could be a family step challenge, creating an in-home circuit exercise routine, or setting a timer that would go off reminding everyone when it is time to stand, stretch, walk, climb a set of stairs, or even garden.

By setting a daily goal and working towards it, you are participating in a nationwide health movement that is bigger than you are! If everyone put a focus on their daily health goals, imagine how healthy our community would be. It is cool to be leading healthy lifestyle changes as a kid. We think it is pretty amazing and are proud of you!

It is important for both parents and kids to know that health is something you work at every day.

Hello, Heart Hero!

Welcome to Day 3 of the Virtual Kids Heart Challenge!

Want to know the best way to feel accomplished today? If you haven’t already, join the nearly 70,000 families who have completed Finn’s Missions! You’ll learn important skills in the mission like hands-only CPR and the warning signs for stroke.

Finn has so much to offer to help your student understand the importance of being heart healthy – log in to your headquarters to get started!

Watch this video to learn all about Finn and why you should complete his missions!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BT8UG88nMPk
https://www2.heart.org/site/SPageNavigator/khc_resources_search.html

Did you know that you can learn Hands-Only CPR as a family in the comfort of your own home?

While you are cooped up at home, help your family learn this lifesaving skill. Our friends at the American Heart Association envision a world where no one dies from cardiac arrest. By learning the two simple steps of Hands-Only CPR, you are preparing your family to help save a life – potentially a life of someone they love!

Take a look at a few of Mrs. Autry's art students, grade 6-8 working on a creative activity that begins with a random doodle, then they noodle the doodle, which means applying algorithms to take the doodle to the next level.
“The backbone of science is logic and experimentation. The basis of art is intuition and insight. They complement rather than contradict each other.”
Through class discussion the students came up with this: A scientific discovery has no meaning unless it can be put to use through problem solving, creative thinking, insight, intuition and innovation. Creativity is essential to true discovery. On the flip side, someone can be incredibly creative, dreaming up all kinds of seemingly impossible inventions. Turn those ideas over to the scientific process and what an amazing discovery…the creative idea becomes reality.

Mrs. Nelson's 3rd grade students were engineers. They were challenged to build the tallest building using only 50 toothpicks and gum drops. They learned that triangles make structures stronger and could withstand a lot of force including an "Earthquake".

In science they were exploring what makes a cloud and using warm water in a sealed cup to model how condensation and evaporation happens. A cool side effect of this lesson was learning that when water comes together into bigger drops it turns white. They were also fascinated that they could feel the warmth and moisture and they connected it to going through Fog.

A classroom Containment was called today. A Classroom Containment IS NOT the same as a lockdown. A Classroom Containment could be called for a number of reasons, all of which require our hallways to be clear of students to protect privacy of the individual involved. Examples when this would be used include: medical responders in hallway, drug search, or an individual who may be upset and unable to move into a private location. During a Classroom Containment no threat is posed to students, and they are able to continue their normal activities in the classroom . Again, there is NO danger to students, just an event occurring that requires privacy.
Thank you for your help and support in allowing us to get the situation resolved before releasing students. If you have further questions or comments, please direct them to Executive Director, LeeAnn Prince. Individual privacy will be maintained and no further details about this specific incidence will be shared.

Last week in Mrs. Betz 1st grade class they celebrated the 100th day of school. The class did 5 STEM stations all centered around the number 100. At one center the students were given 100 blocks to build a tall building. At another station students were given 100 popsicle sticks, 100 straws, and 100 paper clips. They had to use the scientific method to make a hypothesis on how far each of those items would go when stacked end to end. At the next center they were given 100 marshmallows and 100 toothpicks and had design their own houses. At the next station they were given 100 paper cups that they had to stack into a large tower without it falling down. At the last rotation they were given 100 shape pieces and they had to come up with a team picture.
In Mrs. Betz class they have a huge focus on team work and live by the motto "mistakes are proof that you are trying" so everyone was encouraged to collaborate with their peers to accomplish the task. Sometimes the idea will work and sometimes they don't. Those mistakes help use learn. That is a part of being a scientist.

post_text: Mrs Michaelsens' 2nd grade class has been learning about the water cycle. For their STEM activity they were each able to make their own Water Cycle Bag. This bag represents how the water cycle realistically works. In nature, the sun's heat causes water to evaporate from bodies of water. As the water vapor rises it condenses to form clouds when it reaches cooler air. When the clouds are full of water, they release some of the water as rain and the cycle continues. They same principle can be applied to our experiment. We started by drawing the water cycle on our bag to show where precipitation, condensation, and evaporation occur. We then filled all the bags with the same amount of water and hung it in our window so that it could have sunlight. Over the course of a few days the water has warmed up in the sunlight and evaporated some of the water into vapor. As it has cooled it has began changing back into a liquid just like a cloud!

Join Move Utah and the Utah Department of Transportation (UDOT) in raising awareness of pedestrian safety and encouraging folks to walk more during the week of September 30 – October 5 and the entire month of October in 2019.

On average, 42 lives are lost each year in auto-pedestrian crashes in Utah, which accounts for approximately 15% of all fatalities on Utah roads. Even a single pedestrian fatality is too many for Utah.

By walking more in October, you’ll improve your personal health, while also increasing awareness of pedestrian safety across Utah.

Pedestrian safety is up to everyone. Be alert when you’re driving and be seen when you are a pedestrian. If we can share the road, we can reach our goal of Zero Fatalities. #BeSeenBeSafe
visit move.utah.gov/utah-walk-week to learn more

post_text:
Today is National Tape Measure Day.

Alvin J. Fellows of New Haven, Connecticut made the lives of carpenters, electricians, seamstresses, and countless other tradesmen and craftsmen easier. On July 14, 1868, Fellows was granted a patent for “Improvements in Tape Measures” that created a whole new era for measurement. Enter the generation of retractable tape measures.

The first recorded use of the tape measure goes back to the Romans, utilizing marked strips of leather. Before Fellows’ patent, Englishman James Chesterman designed a steel measuring tape, but it was expensive for its time. At $17 in 1853, it was equivalent to $300 in today’s U.S. dollars. Chesterman’s big, bulky design didn’t fit in a pocket or even a toolbox. When Fellows’ patent came along, tape measures became the sliced bread of the toolbox.

https://nationaldaycalendar.com/national-tape-measure-day-july-14/
